Create a stub article
The important thing when creating an article is that it contains basic information, otherwise the draft may be deleted without having had a chance to be improved.
• Start with a definition or description of the topic, which can then serve as an introduction to the article.
• Identify the boundaries, for example by dates of birth and death, if it is a biography, or location, if it is a place.
• Add categories to article creation to increase its visibility for project members.
Then we can:
• expand on this basic information. Research should provide an outline of the topic. The most important thing is to give, in a few clear and concise sentences, a general overview of the topic and/or the issues it raises;
• create some links to other articles, which will help the reader to contextualize the subject, failing to have a complete treatment.
Since a stub is an article like any other in terms of facts, it must respect the founding principles of the encyclopedia, in particular neutrality of point of view . To get started, see also the standard article outlines in Category:Article template , including the example below:
Detailed help: Project:Biology/Draft taxon plan .
A section of an existing article can be flagged as empty, insufficiently detailed, or incomplete using the {{...}} template .
How to improve a draft?
Related article: Help:How to write a good article .
1. Establish a simple plan that covers the subject: for example, cover the history, how it works, a description of its characteristics (geographical, social, economic), its consequences, etc .;
2. Find sources to fill each section with content.

guidelines_for_stub: Start with a definition or description of the topic
Identify boundaries (e.g., dates for biography, location for places)
expansion_steps: Expand on basic information with research-based outline
Create links to other articles for context
draft_improvement_steps: Establish a simple plan (history, characteristics, consequences, etc.)
